Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CEDAR--Correlative Study of Metal Atoms and Ion Concentrations Using Simultaneous and Common Volume Multi-lidar and Radar Measurements at Arecibo
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators will conduct a comprehensive study of the chemistry and dynamics in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) using existing and new data. The tasks include the development of a new radar capability to measure nighttime Fe+ concentrations, and enhanced lidar capabilities for temperature and wind measurements. The objectives are to characterize relationships among atomic metals and electron concentration, compare chemistries of meteoric species in MLT through simultaneous observations, and investigate the response of metal layers to gravity waves and tides. In the last two decades, there have been a number of simultaneous and common volume observations of meteoric species, including, Ca, Fe, K, Na, and Ca+, as well as electron concentration (Ne) and temperature in the mesopause region at Arecibo. The simultaneous observation of multiple species offers the advantage that the atmospheric conditions are identical. With the anticipated radar measurement of Fe+, the observations will allow for comparative studies on ion-molecular and neural-molecular chemistries. Also, the influence of dynamical versus chemical transport and its variation with the altitude will be investigated. The study will help in the development of atmospheric models and improve knowledge of mesospheric chemistry and dynamics. It will involve graduate and undergraduate students from Miami University, as well as students from universities in Puerto Rico, and will strengthen international collaborations with scientists from at least two other countries. The results are expected to help to improve atmospheric models used by the broader atmospheric community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was extremely successful and resulted in scientific advancement related to the Earth’s upper atmosphere. The mesospheric and the lower thermospheric (MLT) region that extends between 80 – 110 km has often been referred to as the “ignosphere” since it is too high for balloons and too low for satellites to access. Several important processes, for example, gravity-wave dissipation, instabilities, turbulence, etc., occur in this region. Resonance lidars have helped enhance the knowledge about MLT region by proving high-resolution data from a single location. The unique instrument cluster at Arecibo (AO) is well suited for studying MLT region and uses state-of-the-art systems. Simultaneous measurements using optical and radar instruments at AO have shed new light on several processes occurring in the Earth’s upper atmosphere. The scientific results have appeared in several peer-reviewed journals, and some major contributions are summarized below.

 Combined incoherent scatter radar (ISR) and resonance lidar observations are crucial for understanding ion-neutral coupling in the MLT region. Sporadic-E (Es) is characterized by the occurrence of a thin layer of ionization below 130 km. The influence of Es layers on the neutrals can be studied using resonance lidars at AO. The proposal allowed us to investigate the impact of Es on different neutral metals like Na  (alkali) and Fe (non-alkali). This study revealed that an Es layer with electron concentrations [Ne] less than 600 electrons cm-3, was accompanied by a strong Na enhancement and a weak sporadic Fe (Fes) layer around 95-km altitude. The difference in structuring of the layers was attributed to temperature dependent ion-molecule chemistry [Raizada et al., 2015a].

 We also found that the tidal ion layers (TILs), which are a common feature over Arecibo and are frequently observed as the descending layers in the ISR data, are not correlated with the neutral thermospheric metal layers above 120 km. This study implied that a new mechanism other than neutralization of ions within the TILs, need to be considered for the source of the metals above 120 km [Raizada et al., 2015b].

 The work we performed allowed us to train several students at undergraduate levels from local as well other U.S. universities. The local students represented under-represented Hispanic population in the science and technology field.

The peer-reviewed publications resulting from this grant are listed below:

  1. Y. X., Q. Zhou, F. Yi, J. Friedman, S. Raizada, and C. Tepley (2016), Simultaneous and common-volume lidar observations of K/Na layers and temperature at Arecibo Observatory (18°N, 67°W), J. Geophys. Res. Atmos., 121, 8038–8054, DOI:10.1002/ 2015JD024494.
  2. S. Raizada, C. M. Brum, C. A. Tepley, J. Lautenbach, J. S. Friedman, J. D. Mathews, F. T. Djuth, and C. Kerr (2015a), First simultaneous measurements of Na and K thermospheric layers along with TILs from Arecibo, Geophys. Res. Lett., 42, DOI:10.1002/2015GL066714.
  3. S. Raizada, C. A. Tepley. Q. Zhou, S. Sarkhel. J. D. Mathews, N. A, Aponte, I. Sekar, R. Kerr, and E. Cabassa (2015b), Dependence of mesospheric Na and Fe distributions on electron density at Arecibo, Earth, Planet and Space,  67:146, DOI 10.1186/s40623-015-0322-z.
  4. S. Sarkhel, J. D. Mathews, S. Raizada, R. Sekar, D. Chakrabarty, A. Guharay, R. B. Kerr, G. Ramkumar, S. Sridharan, Q. Wu, M. G. Mlynczak, and J. M. Russell III (2015), A case study on occurrence of an unusual structure in the sodium layer over Gadanki, India, Earth, Planet and Space, DOI:10.1186/s40623-015-0183-5.
  5. Y., X., Q. Zhou, S. Raizada, C.A. Tepley, and J. F. Friedman (2013), Relationship between mesospheric Na and Fe layers from simultaneous and common-volume lidar observations at Arecibo, J. Geophys. Res DOI: 10.1002/jgrd.50148.

The PI and other investigators have presented several research papers at international meetings and conferences:

  1. S. Raizada and C. G. Brum, Ionospheric response at Arecibo during St. Patrick storm. Cedar Workshop, Santa Fe, NM 20 – 24 June 2016.
  2. J. S. Friedman, S. Raizada, C. Brum, J. Lautenbach, C. Kerr, J. D. Mathews, F. Djuth. Metal layers in the thermosphere at Arecibo, Cedar Workshop, Santa Fe, NM 20 – 24 June 2016.
  3. J. Lautenbach, S. Raizada, and J. S. Friedman, Proposing an upgrade of the Arecibo lidar system to enhance science capabilities, Cedar Workshop, Santa Fe, NM 20 – 24 June 2016.
  4. S. Raizada, J. D. Mathews, J. Friedman, F. Djuth, C, Brum, and C. A. Tepley (2015). High altitude metal observations from Arecibo: Evidence of sputtering. Presented at the Stanford Meteor Environment and Effects (SMEE) Workshop. Stanford University, San Francisco, CA.
  5. S. Raizada, C. G. M. Brum, C. Gonzalez, and E. Franco (2015). Nighttime E-region column average variability over Arecibo: Seasonal and solar activity dependencies of column average concentration. AOGS 2015. Singapore.
  6. J. D. Mathews, V. Kesaraju, R. Dinsmore, and S. Raizada (2015). Meteoroid sputtering and lower-thermosphere metals. Stanford Meteor Environment and Effects Workshop. Stanford University, San Francisco, CA.
